page.title: 01The Snowdon Massif
page.content: This area covers the summit of Snowdon, 1085 metres above sea level, and the ridges which meet at this point. In the north west the land drops steeply to the Llanberis Pass only 208 metres above sea level; and in the south west to Llyn Llydaw; an in hospitable mountain lake. Over 400,000 people walk on the paths which lead to the summit each year and these are becoming badly eroded. National Park Wardens & volunteers are trying to allay the situation. Day trippers use the mountain railway to ride to the summit from Spring until Autumn. Most of this area however has only visits by rock climbers, feral goats and peregrine falcons since the rock faces and gulleys deter the majority.
